Warning: IANAL but I had to listen to one explaining the GDPR to me for an entire semester a few years ago:

There is a mechanism in GDPR called "legitimate interest" that can allow processing without explicit consent (note that this legitimate interest must have been established after an internal process in the company that is working with your data and cannot be assumed as given) in certain cases. If my memory from my lecture about legitimate interest serves me right is is possible to establish legitimate interest within the framework of GDPR for the purposes of direct advertisement, in particular also when the data used for this is made public. I'm not saying that this is what happened here or that I'm fine with this behavior, but just because you didn't consent does not mean there is a GDPR violation.

Why do people view this email negatively, apart from the possibly scraped emails (most academic's emails are probably posted on the internet openly, so I don't see this as a big issue anyway)?
I ask because I filled out their form (including the three exercises there), and received a request to schedule a meeting with them. Is there anything I should be aware of when considering collaborating with them?

Because I don't like being lied to, as well as dealing with people that handle my data sloppily, as well as in violation of the law.

I'm sure the company is able to cough up some money to people to generate training data for them, else they wouldn't be doing this spamming campaign.

Don't they offer pretty good pay though? I see this as no different from receiving an employment email from some tech company with an offer to interview (I personally don't mind and even welcome them because more options is better than fewer options).
Regardless of the data handling issue, I sense that there is a negative sentiment regarding this whole operation. Why is that?

There are thousands of people on this zulip, none of whom have entered their email address with the expectation that it would be used for indiscriminate cold emailing for opportunities like this. I imagine people would be less bothered if those were individual emails sent to that person for a specific reason. (I find recruiters emailing out of the blue without having the slightest clue who I am or why I'd be a good candidate equally annoying, fwiw.) There's a whole stream on this server for people to announce job positions as well.

They also obviously did not hand check before sending. I have no involvement with the lean community except for 1 message 3 years ago.

If every project that was looking for lean or in general technical specialists would do stuff like this and a large amount of people would find this cool we would suffer a https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tragedy_of_the_commons where the law-abiding not-spamming companies find it more difficult to find employees, while it becomes more difficult for job-seekers to find relevant employment
